name: Chemical Equations
what: Chemical equations represent reactions using either words (word equations) or chemical symbols and formulas (symbol equations). They show what reacts and what is produced.
why: Chemical equations are the language scientists use to communicate precisely about reactions. They allow you to see exactly which elements are involved and in what amounts.

items.title: I can write word equations for chemical reactions
items.what: Word equations show reactants on the left, an arrow meaning 'produces', and products on the right. Multiple reactants or products are separated by plus signs.
items.why: Word equations are a simple way to describe reactions in plain language before moving to more detailed symbol equations.
items.example: For the reaction of sodium with oxygen: sodium + oxygen ‚Üí sodium oxide. The arrow shows that sodium and oxygen react to produce sodium oxide.

items.title: I can convert word equations to symbol equations
items.what: Symbol equations replace substance names with their chemical formulas. This shows exactly which elements are present and how many atoms of each are in the compounds.
items.why: Symbol equations provide more information than word equations, showing the exact composition of all substances involved.
items.example: The word equation 'hydrogen + oxygen ‚Üí water' becomes the symbol equation 'H‚ÇÇ + O‚ÇÇ ‚Üí H‚ÇÇO'. This shows that hydrogen and oxygen molecules combine to form water molecules.

items.title: I can interpret chemical formulas in equations
items.what: In symbol equations, subscripts show atoms within a molecule and coefficients (numbers in front) show how many molecules are involved. To find total atoms, multiply coefficient by subscript.
items.why: Correctly counting atoms is essential for understanding reactions and checking whether equations are balanced.
items.example: In 2H‚ÇÇO, the coefficient 2 means two water molecules. Each water molecule has 2 hydrogen atoms, so total hydrogen = 2 √ó 2 = 4 atoms. Total oxygen = 2 √ó 1 = 2 atoms.

items.title: I can use state symbols in chemical equations
items.what: State symbols show the physical state of each substance: (s) for solid, (l) for liquid, (g) for gas, and (aq) for aqueous (dissolved in water).
items.why: State symbols provide important information about the conditions of a reaction and the physical form of reactants and products.
items.example: AgNO‚ÇÉ(aq) + NaCl(aq) ‚Üí AgCl(s) + NaNO‚ÇÉ(aq) shows that silver nitrate and sodium chloride solutions react to form solid silver chloride and sodium nitrate solution.

items.title: I can explain the difference between coefficients and subscripts
items.what: Subscripts are part of the chemical formula and show atoms within a single molecule. Coefficients are placed before formulas and show how many molecules are present. Only coefficients can be changed when balancing.
items.why: Changing subscripts would create different substances, while changing coefficients just changes the amount of each substance.
items.example: H‚ÇÇO and H‚ÇÇO‚ÇÇ are completely different substances (water vs hydrogen peroxide). But 2H‚ÇÇO just means two water molecules instead of one.
